title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: In threeweeks the minister had brought the evil parish of Dour into the presenceof God.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: And thewind wafted to the weeping wives in the cottages of the stricken parishof Dour the sound of the hoarse and broken singing of men.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: The next day all the men that were alive in the parish ofDour stood about the minister's grave in the kirkyard on the hill.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: They carried him to the manse of Dour, and weptas they went.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: For the first time since the minister came to Dour, the kirk-bell didnot ring on Sabbath, for the minister was at the other end of the parishsetting a house in order whence three children had been carried.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: Then came Abraham Ligartwood out of the manse of Dour.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: In Dourthe horses starved in the stables, the cattle in the byres.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: At least it is sure that it was to his house that theDeath first came in the parish of Dour.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: But in the fall of the year the White Death came to Dour.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: There was no child baptized in theparish of Dour; and no wholesome diets of catechising, where old andyoung might learn the Way more perfectly.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: The footfall of the minister of Dour as hepaced alone in his study chilled them to the bone.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: At this the parish of Dour seethed with rebellion.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: "It is the destruction of God's good creature!" said the parish of Dour.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: Writs from the authority mentioned did not runin the parish of Dour.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: But at night seventeen of his kirkmembers in good standing and fourteen adherents met at the Back Spitalof Port Dour to drink prosperity to the cargo which had been safely run.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: This cargo-running and seizures were all according to rule, and theminister of Dour had nothing to say.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: One night there was a fine cargo cleanly run at Port Saint Johnston, thevillage next to Dour.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: But the parish of Dour was to get news ofthe minister, for Abraham Ligartwood was not a man to trifle with.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: The parish of Dour laughed.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: But Dour did not at that time know the minister.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: Dour smiled complacently, andconsidered that its hoary wickednesses would beat the minister in thelong-run.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: Dour was agarden filled with the degenerate fruit of a strange vine.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: When he came to the parish of Dour he found that he hadto succeed a man who had allowed his people to run wild.

author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: The manse ofDour was conspicuously set like a watch-tower on a hill--or like abaron's castle above the huts of his retainers.

author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
